I actually hate this game with unbridled terrifying passion. I have removed it from my life, so I actually do not own it any more. It stands here to remind me to never, ever play this game again. Is it good? Yes! Do I rather cut down a three and chop the wood into bits and eat them with vinegar? Also Yes. BGG, why is there no option "Voluntarily destroyed" to describe the accurate status of my game? People should be allowed to burn this game. There are some redeeming qualities. Like you could put valuables in this box because nobody will ever think anything valuable is in it. I hate it so much. If I ever had a billion euros I would buy all copies and put them a mile underground. Although it would probably be reprinted then. Streisand effect. So a better idea is to pay off the creator to never republish. And bribe Google, Reddit and Youtube to remove any and all mention of this game. And pay BGG a motherload of money to reduce the Diplomacy BGG rating with several 10000 positions and give random 404 errors on the Diplomacy game page. This game is poison on your social life. This game makes you hate your backstabbing friends. This game makes you backstab your friends and end friendships. This game is like Monopoly, a game designed to prove a point (War with friends is bad hmkay) and people mistake it for being good. I loathe this game. It should be named "Ultimate Dissapointment" or "Fun Debilitating Time Wastement". Rip this game to shreds when you see it. Stamp on it with your feet. Burn the remains. Nuke it from orbit. If you even need kindling to start a BBQ, go get this game and throw it in there. Mail it to your ex-wife. Use it's components to fill a cardbox to protect other sold worthy boardgames from damage while being transported. This is the 100% opposite of KLASK, which is the boardgame that could save humanity. Diplomacy is the boardgame that could start Nuclear War and end humanity. It's the Middle East of boardgaming.

A simple, accessible game that hides a brutal, unfair experience. In most games, especially when playing with experienced players, a few people will be eliminated very early on, often with little they can do about it. Usually I don’t mind player elimination too much, but in a game that’s six hours long… It can make people never want to play games again. There are no words to adequately describe how much I detest this thing. It is so mean-spirited by design that it can actually destroy friendships and drive you away from board gaming as a hobby. The dictionary defines diplomacy as, "the art of dealing with people in a sensitive and effective way". If you believe that means lying, selfish exploitation of others, and backstabbing, then this vile thing is for you.

There's so little detail in the military aspect of the game that really it could have been anything else without anything being lost; rather than armies and fleets taking over supply centres to make more armies and fleets it could have been investors putting money in businesses to make more money. There's no morale, no terrain (so for example defending in Italy isn't any easier than attacking in Russia), no quality (so for example a Russian army will fight as well as a German one even though the actual warfare of the time shows very much otherwise), no supplies (so an army half the continent away will fight as well as if it was in its country's capital). Clearly the board was designed to make numbers and therefore alliances the key to winning even though in real life leadership, training and better weapons make the difference. When the board could as easily have been anything else there isn't much point to there being physical locations at all; it could have just been a series of counters and tracks and instead of moving pieces around you just negotiate for this and that which is really all the game is anyway.
Don't get me started on the online community of the boardgame...

There are a lot of games that do the same in a much efficient and funnier way. No one should be playing this game anymore.

In terms of raw game quality Diplomacy probably deserves a better ranking than this. But at this end of the scale the real criterion is "Which game is a less colossal waste of my time", and Diplomacy is a very long game.

The single worst game ever made.

It is an epic fail as a "war game," and no matter what crusty grogs say, it is a war game with a negotiating aspect.

You have an early 20th century European power. On a given turn, you make plans on what to do this turn with other players. Then you write down your orders and simultaneously reveal them. Because you are not obligated to do what you promised to do, there is a certain amount of back-stabbing that may or may not go on.

Each area can only contain 1 cube. These cubes represent armies. You win combat by attacking an adjacent area while another one "supports" your attack. Without the numerical advantage, you cannot win.

Pretty simple concept, right? So why does it suck? Historically, it fails. Anyone can form an alliance with anybody else. France & Germany are not going going to ally and stick it to Austria-Hungary, who is not going to ally with Russia.

The next fail is that all sides are basically equal in power and all armies are the same. Because Russia starts out with an extra piece, they are actually more powerful than Germany -- in 1900. In what universe?

And then there's the combat system. That is a system so lame-brained, it screams "Eurogame!"

You could assuage some of the flaws of the game by making a generic map and taking away the ahistorical flaws, but you are still left with a boring game that takes way too long to play with too little payoff.

And if you play with the wrong group, you might lose some friends when it's all said and done, but if that's the case, you shouldn't be playing with them because the ties of friendship should be stronger than board games.

It might appeal to certain people who find the United Nations general assembly fascinating, but I do not want, even for one minute, to hang out with people like that. I'd like to state the following for the record: If you lost (or could lose) a friend because of this game, you are a blithering idiot. What kind of wanker would break a friendship over any game, let alone one this excruciatingly dull? With its moronic all-units-are-identical setup, the endless negotiations and a so-dumb-I-can't-believe-it's-not-a-joke combat system, a session of Diplomacy rivals C-Span for tediousness and dental surgery for unpleasantness. Scheming and wanking, scheming and wanking. I'd rather be stretched thin, twisted into a meat pretzel and shoved up a donkey's bunghole.

Diplomacy is a war/negotiation game set in the years leading up to WWI. The 7 major European countries are represented on the board, which is in fact a map of Europe. To win, a player has to control 18 specially marked provinces on the board. Every country starts with three of these provinces, except Russia, which starts with four. In order for anyone to do well at all they are going to have to form alliances with other players. However, these alliances are fragile at best as players never know how much to trust each other, and are always looking for an opportunity to turn on their allies when it's most advantageous.

Diplomacy is an incredibly well thought out game. All countries have more-or-less even strength to start, and are immediately threatened by at least two other neighbouring countries. I really appreciate and applaud the game for its design.

I hate long games. I just don't want to invest hours upon hours of time to one game. Despite this I really wanted to try Diplomacy, which has a reputation of going long. Now I've played it, and my desire to play has been quenched - forever. This is why I rate Diplomacy a 2. It's because a 2 indicates that I never want to play the game again. For one thing, the game had gone seven hours before the first (and as it turned out only) player was eliminated. A big reason for the length is that you can only go so far before getting bogged down in stand-offs with other countries' military units. These impasses are frequent, and slow progress down considerably. Second, you have to lie to other players and stab them in the back. This is known about the game, and my group even discussed it before we started. We reminded ourselves that it's only a game, so don't get too upset when someone turns on you. However, when I stabbed my friend in the back, who thought we had a rock-solid alliance, he was angry. I didn't like making him feel that way. I also didn't like betraying his trust in me, even though it was only within the game. I've realized that if a game causes negative emotions I'm just not into it. I sold my copy of Intrigue after one play for this same reason.

So, I doubt I'll ever play Diplomacy again. For the reasons mentioned I can't recommend the game either.

I probably couldn't count the number of miserable times I have had with this Diplomacy. The game itself has virtually no mechanics, so gameplay relies entirely on user interaction - before every turn players discuss with each other their plans for expansion and work deals out based on that. The way we played, everyone met each other one to one in private and exchanged their "strategies." What this boils down to is making empty promises, getting frustrated that other people break theirs, and way more time wasting than should be ever reasonable for a board game. Even worse, I have found that as time goes on people take the game more and more seriously and pretty much everyone gets angry and bitter towards one another. Not at all my idea of a fun board game night.

Some of my most fond gaming memories are based around Diplomacy. I can remember playing games of it at college, where we would all submit turns twice a day and discuss moves during classes. I can remember multiple other games where we would show up at someone's house and play until the wee hours of the morning, getting angry at each other for betrayals and then immediately offering to ally again as soon as the moment was right.

I can also remember that I've literally never finished a game. I've also had people who got mad enough to not talk to me for days afterwards, and while I'm sure the majority of that blame is on me, I can't help but feel that the game brings it out of people as well.

It's an experience that I think everyone should have at least once, but I honestly don't think it's a very good game. Mechanically it's nothing incredible, and other games can fill a similar niche in far less time.

In short, I look back on Diplomacy fondly, but I would not recommend it as a good game, and would also be unlikely to play it again.

Eerily, (and I can't really explain how this came about) when push came to shove, and my friends and I pulled out the knives, we were all either emotionally bothered by the impact it had on us, or on other players at the table. Something happened. Despite the fact that we knew going in NOT to take anything personal, it stopped feeling like a game, and started feeling like what would happen if people were really acting this way.

We didn't like causing each other to feel that way seriously, even though it was just because of things going on in the game. I've realized something about games from playing Diplomacy, that "it's just a game" only carries so far. Even though I really, really appreciate the uniqueness and structure of this game, I'll be surprised if I can really bring myself to play it again. I used to be the person who said "If your friendship takes a hit over a game, what kind of friendship was it really?" It's just, in a way, it stopped feeling like a game. And it just wasn't the kind of game I ever wanted to play again.

I think this game has been eclipsed by others that use its diplomacy, non-dice rolling mechanic. Even though I like the principles of the game in general you need too many players to play it and the game is so darned stressful that I don't find myself wanting to play often.

I find that the game plays much better by e-mail and actually plays the best online with people you don't know--having plenty of time for negotiations (days) means that calculations are less chaotic and stabs are better planned and less emotional--the game takes on a little bit more logic.

Something like Game of Thrones completely fires Diplomacy for me.

Finally, I don't know what else to say other than that there are some poor design problems like the common stalemate positions in the game. I suppose you could argue that all the players usually know about them so it's not a problem but I still think it is a problem. Add in the unbalanced starts which I am normally fully in support of. Some players in a vastly better position than others and game design has to come into question.

I'm just don't have the fortitude to endure this game, although the diceless and cooperative-while-simultaneously-backstabbing element of the game is very unique and clever. Also another complaint: the cooperative win condition of the game enabled me to win my first game (played during my junior year of high school, on the only day of classes i ever skipped) when I, playing as England, realized that between myself and Russia (whom I'd never interacted with or cooperated with for the whole game) could win the game simply by declaring an alliance, because between us we had enough regions to win. A very lackluster finish. (but of course, I couldn't avoid the opportunity to win it as soon as possible, given how sick I felt at backstabbing by best friend as Germany).

A final note: I've seen so many people get so upset at people lying to them, that the bad feeling has persisted beyond the game. I know that lying/deception is a part of many games that I really enjoy (e.g. poker), but I guess the directness and the extent to which you must lie and betray an ally in this game for the ploy to be successful makes the consequences a little more severe. This is the one game I think would be much better to play with strangers than with friends. (although, on second thought, Poker too might often be better played with strangers)...
For this final issue, another point is deducted from that 5.

I've clinged to my Asmodée edition of Diplomacy from the longest of time, as its austere map, paper notes, wooden discs and metallic sculpts gave off the aura of a gentleman's strategy game. But the requirements to get the full experience are so steep that I don't know I'll ever play it again: 7 players, 7+ hours. And these players must have an understanding of the 20+ subrules of the resolution phase of simultaneous movement in order to plan accordingly. And these players must be willing to roam the rooms of a flat, holding a whole bunch of private conversations/negotiations for often 15 minutes before deciding on their moves for the turn. And these players must be understanding of and in agreement with the idea that they might get eliminated early on while the remainder of the game goes on for hours; and that the reason for it is that everything they've spent hours of energy and emotion building has been casually swiped away by the betrayal of a promise from someone they otherwise hold dear. Assembling such a crowd is a tough ask.

I could entertain myself in the illusion that one day, when the stars align, I'll dust off my old box and it will have been so worth it. But my discovery of the online digital world of Diplomacy has made me realise that we're really talking about a game that was made for asynchronous play-by-mail and which, played properly, results in an awful amount of stalemate joint ties; which I'm not that interested in.

I've tried playing this in a more "neutral" setting where I know few, if any, of the players in the game. While still somewhat interesting tactically and strategically, I found the game loses a lot of its charm in such settings, as I try to negotiate with people I don't even know (or possibly even like), and in the end I don't care as much whether I succeed or fail. It's kind of like watching a mediocre movie sequel - you like the characters and the theme, but overall the movie is just meh. Plus, the thing just takes too damned long.

These days I would always pick a game like Imperial over this, which is a lot shorter, and has the added dimension of a majority shareholder that can take your military powerhouse away from you, or Here I Stand if I want a game that still involves some private negotiation, but isn't centered on it.

Anyway, thanks for the memories.

Had a lot of fun (and frustration) back in the days of play by mail (and email). The nature of the game is making temporary allies, but being ready to backstab them when the time is right.

Critical to the game is the process of talking to enemies and allies. Secondary are the actual mechanics of moving armies and fleets (mastered quickly). Those with a keen understanding of human nature and able to think and talk fast are rewarded rather than those with clever strategy. The game closely mirrors life with its undeserved failures and unexpected successes. Diplomacy is a great game.

Having said all that, the game does encourage "negative" behaviour - you *will* be forced on occasion to lie, use coercion or threats, be forced to trust an opponent known to be lying, etc. These aspects are all part of the rough and tumble of the game (which some love and others loathe).

Also, finding 6 players to play for 3+ hours is near impossible, so I rather recommend the excellent 2-player variant Intimate Diplomacy. ID removes the lying, back-stabbing and other negative aspects of 7-player Dip, but retains the rich game play. Its also takes less than half the time to play!

I have many fond memories of college, one of which is Diplomacy and the many games of it played. Some finished, many not, Diplomacy holds a high ranking based largely on respect. The pure, simple mechanisms make for a very engaging game. Like many of my top ranked games, it's a game that demands a lot of its players to be successful. Intense negotiation, social engineering, and constant paranoia are the tenants of Diplomacy, and 50+ years later it's still something that stands on its own.

The game is mechanically better than my rating reflects. I appreciate it as a design but no longer have the enthusiasm or resilience to play such a potentially devastating game over so many hours.

I was introduced to this game as an alternative to the luck-driven game "Risk." by a USMC friend who had an older version with painted wooden armies and navies. The "no dice involved" aspect fascinated me, as it became evident that the outcome of the game was a direct result of the actions (and inactions, and diplomatic maneuverings) of the players rather than sheer luck. The premise to the game, as I see it, is: convince all the other players that you should be the game's winner through military force, coerscion, subterfuge, or, as many nations have done through the years, deceit and surprise.

Though I own this newer version of the game, I'd love to own the more "classic" version(s) of it. Failing that, I'll attempt to replace the cardboard counters of my more current version with painted figurines to represent the armies (artillery pieces), navies (battleships of the era), and supply centers (factories).

超主观点评（7人局）：
1、不愧是从1959年传承至今的经典，虽然画风、配件和玩法都比较简单，但是背景和游戏结合得很好，玩起来也很流畅，当说服（忽悠）别人按照自己的意图行动时非常有成就感。
2、支援和护送都可以寻求别的国家帮助，这就让变数更多了，随时被背刺，也经常因为指令配合不好变成废指令，真是太真实了。
3、同时行动很好，但是写指令有点累，感觉像权力的游戏那样用指令token控制会更方便。
小心得：
1、我们觉得控制的兵力多的时候写指令有点累，就村成了控制8个补给中心游戏结束，结果发现8个太快了，第二年就结束了，有点人都还没反应过来，感觉还是10-12个补给中心比较合适。
2、土耳其、俄罗斯、英格兰早期蛮强的，因为没有后顾之忧。我用的土耳其，感觉在黑海这个地方挺微妙的。
3、船能下海还是尽量下海，进可攻退可守，不仅方便投运兵力，支援的地方也比较多，而且要消灭或者驱逐船还是比较难的。
玩法：
大家随意交流战术之后，秘密对自己的每个部队书写指令，指令有4种，一是坚守、二是移动、三是支援、四是护送。所有兵种的战力都为1，想击败别人就要数量比别人多。冬季根据部队所在位置，确认占领的补给中心，然后根据补给中心数量解散（任意地方）或征召（在自己的本土）部队。

Diplomacy is a game I would easily give a 10, but it’s a tough one to get to the table. The ideal player count is 7, and it’s not always easy to round up that many people who want to play this kind of game. However, when the stars align, the strategic moments this game offers are some of the best I’ve ever experienced. With minimal mechanics but incredibly deep strategy, it’s a game that rewards negotiation, alliances, and betrayal in equal measure.

To keep the game moving and add an extra layer of chaos, I use a few house rules:

5-minute Diplomacy phases and 1-minute writing orders phases: This keeps the game fast-paced and intense, forcing players to make quick decisions and preventing it from dragging on.
Flashcards for writing orders: These add a fun roleplay element and help immerse players in the game's tense atmosphere. The physical act of writing orders on flashcards feels fitting and keeps everyone engaged.

Despite its challenges in setting up, Diplomacy is a masterpiece of strategic gameplay, and the low mechanics but high stakes make it an unforgettable experience when it does hit the table.
Some of my most fun strategic experiences in my early adult gaming life were with this game.

The difficulties are:
- Finding enough players who are happy* to spend the time needed to play a 5-to-10-hour game and who are okay with deceiving and/or being deceived within the context of the game and its rules. Even if you find a full seven players who can agree to the above at a specific time, what if one of them drops out? Do you invite an extra player just in case? What do they do if everyone shows? The game is long enough to be an event, but sensitive to the precise player count.
- Player eliminations. The game is too long to have someone sit and watch after being eliminated. I have some thoughts on a modified form of the game that could help with this, but meanwhile, see MrSmith's suggestions, below.
- Typically, underwhelming and unrealistic consequences to not keeping your word. Maybe a mob or career theme would be more appropriate to the core strategy of backstabbing.
- Kingmaking

*I say 'happy' because one should never play a game with someone who wants to not play the game, and one should not attempt to play a long game with someone who is only content to play.

For myself and perhaps others to try, I repeat here a suggestion from 'MrSmith' on how to play with non-hardcore players:
"
IMPERATIVE HOME RULES FOR FRIENDLY PLAY UNDER 3 HOURS:
1. NO BACK TALKING (reduces 30% length): No one leaves the table (except for emergencies :-) ). Communication is open or made through written secret short notes.
2. NO ELIMINATION (reduces 30% length): When one or more powers reach 0 or 1 supply centers, the game ends immediately. Player with most supply centers wins.
3. NO BACKSTABBING: [this would drastically alter the tone of the game] Before attacking, supporting an attack or entering a nation's home territory, a declaration of war (DoW) must be issued at the beginning of the orders writing phase. In order to benefit from another power's unit support, an alliance declaration must also be issued by both powers.
"
Rating is for the '2 player variant' posted to the Forums 20-Apr-2024

Both a game as well as a academic exercise in Neo-realist international relations theory, this game is in many ways the grandfather of all modern strategy games - both board and digital.

Take any strategy boardgame that has been released in the past decade and then strip away all of its 'chrome'; the many rules, point-tracks, tokens and pieces of cardboard that serve to make the game more complicated without adding any meaningful complexity. Once removed, the game that remains is Diplomacy - the grandfather of modern strategy games.

What constitutes complexity in a strategy game? In my view its the players evaluating positions- both their own and those of their opponents. Weighing the strengths and potential weaknesses of each other, trying to figure out whose is ahead and who to gang up on. To do so cooperation is required but trust is a scarce resource. The weak must appear strong to avoid being carved up. The strong must appear weak to prevent alliances against them. Thus everything depends not just on the board state; but the impression the players have of it.

As a consequence, gameplay no longer revolves around some wooden piece on a point track but around the human person sitting opposite of you. Can you trust them? Do they trust you? When they look at the board, do they see the same threats and opportunities as you do? Do your interests align, and if so, when will they start to diverge?

Now, the limited set of rules, uncomplicated by themselves, have created a game that is infinitely complex as they are applied through the social interactions of a table full of people continuously evaluating, judging, scheming, lying and arguing.

Too often boardgames 'kill the table'. With players staring in silence at boards filled tokens and trackers whilst everyone else waits for their turn.

Diplomacy, despite its length, is a fast-paced game. All turns are taken simultaneously with no 'down time' in between. Players do not wait on each other and the table will never be silent. All gameplay is centered on the boardstate and the players. There are no 'secondary player boards', instead you get raw, undistilled strategy - continuous negotiations interrupted by those glorious moments of shock, betrayal, elation, and panic as the board state is updated at the end of each turn.

Simple to learn, with rules that can be explained in a few minutes, yet impossible to master. This timeless classic hasn't aged a bit.

Played my dad's copy of this game a few times in my late teens and no game experience has quite compared for the level of immersion and engagement. I remember sneaking around trying to spy on other negotiations going on round the house. The simplicity of the mechanics are pretty much perfect - no chance, no stacks of cards, just negotiating with (and betraying) your fellow players.

That said, it's long (not sure I ever actually finished the game), needs all seven players, and I think really requires the players to enthusiastically want to get into the spirit of the game. I also can imagine that played with the wrong people it could be quite bullying, but in the games I remember players who were too untrustworthy and duplicitous tended to lose out when other players realised they couldn't be trusted.

Was perfect with a bunch of my late teenage friends, maybe a bit harder to imagine it working out so well now I'm 30. But if you think you have a good group and are keen to try this game, I'd definitely recommend!

I got to play this a lot during High School with my friends. We played so many games, including some online. Therefore it still has a warm spot in my heart, and I do still love it. But I've come to realize that the player elimination aspect coupled with long play time makes it incredibly difficult to get to the table, especially with the 7 player requirement. And even when I do get it to the table, something is missing when playing with newer/inexperienced players who don't know the nuances of the gameplay that can also really impact my enjoyment of playing this one. Still, I will almost always play this if there is a chance to--simply because it is so difficult to get a chance to play.

This is a wonderful game to enjoy and play online async though, in many ways it almost is better there. You can really dive deep in the negotiations and planning that can be difficult to do in a live game. There used to be a rich postal scene for the game, so in some ways it feels like Diplomacy was far ahead of its time and was waiting for the internet to come along and let it really shine. Online the player elimination parts along with requiring exactly 7 players are much easier hurdles to overcome, plus you can't see who is talking to whom which can sometimes kind of spoil the in person experience. Having a computer adjudicate complicated sets of orders is also handy.

Update (May 2023): Upping this to a rightful 9 where it belongs. I still play a few times per year, mostly async, although I do play in person here and there, and have some growing hopes to do so slightly more regularly. Regardless, it still absolutely is an event type game, that is tricky to plan and organize as an adult in the modern game scene, oh to go back to those days of youth where we dove in to this on so many weekends and even some daring weeknights with fast rounds!

Regardless, there is nothing still quite like this. It's so visceral in what it does, it's simply negotiation, but a hell of a lot of it. You plan and plot and try to make allies, then the intense reveal of orders, and you simply do that again and again as a grand epic plays out in front of the players. No randomness, no confusion. The fact you have failed is directly due to the other players take your stuff, and reneging on our plans. That brutal truth can crack friendships as the game infamously is known to do, but that's part of the point here....no other game makes one feel quite so much, and while it can suck to feel that pain, there can be a sort of joy in it? Most games you can care less what happens, and perhaps that is better, but if you want a jolt of emotion with your game, Diplomacy can bring it out far more than anything else.

Is that good? Eh, it's not always something one wants. But given nothing else provides it, I think it's a great design and worth play here and there. You get more intensity and more negotiation out of a good game of Diplomacy than you can in whatever else has come out since.

I often liken this to the TV reality show Survivor--both games are actually social games, where winning requires you to advance your own cause at the expanse of others, and winning often comes with some backstabbing and turning on promises with people you've repeatedly build up alliances and trust with. Winning is therefore quite hard, as you have to manage this path well enough that people want to help you win, even when they know what has happened to get you there. Much like Survivor, players who get eliminated hopefully have the right mindset and understand that it is a game, and one they signed up for, but you still sometimes see those who are enraged and pissed about what has happened, and one time friends can be broken. Diplomacy is known to do that too, although again is it the game's issue, or a player? It perhaps is a bit of both, but the game doesn't hide what is going to happen, and someone teaching it shouldn't hide it either.

In the end, to experience exquisite highs of plans all coming together and masterful manipulations, one has to be prepared for the largest lows you'll get in a game, the unrelenting reality that your ally and friend screwed you over and you're going to lose because of it as everything you worked for and planned has crumbled in the face of the lies, treachery and betrayal.

Again, it may well not be the experience for many, but for anyone who is excited by trying such a thing, nothing will deliver the jolt that Diplomacy so consistently has and does.

Great multiplayer game of international politics - certainly the best introduction to politics (and its intrigues) I know. Diplomacy is a great way to study human behaviour, thinking skills, strategy, and negotiations. Fantastic re-play-ability.

I have organized a Diplomacy game (face-to-face) or a Diplomacy Tournament almost every year since the late 1970s; mostly in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Other locations include: Beaconsfield, Quebec and Baton Rouge, Louisiana and Vancouver, British Columbia. It has been a lot of work but I think this game teaches so many lessons that it deserves special effort to get people together to play this exceptionally great game.

WARNING #1:
Diplomacy can be hard on relationships. Because forming alliances (leaving the possibility of backstabs) is central to the strategy of most games it can be hard for players who find it difficult to be betrayed. Diplomacy can be emotionally challenging when the political realities of self-interest, dishonesty, bad-faith and greed are revealed during games.

On the more positive side; mature adults benefit from the trials associated with the experiences gained from playing Diplomacy. I highly recommend the game for all those who want to understand politics, history or human nature.

WARNING #2
Games require a lot of time to play well. I usually find 6 hours is best. A game can be played in 4 or 5 hours but will not likely lead to a decisive conclusion - even if played for 7 or more hours. Thus it takes a lot of effort to organize a game.

On the positive side; it can be a great game to play over extended periods of time such as once a week. Some of my favourite games when going to University were when we played 2 or 3 moves per week.

This is the ONLY game I’ve rated as 10/10, and that is a serious rating. This game deserves it. Why? The mechanics are simple, there aren’t a lot of pieces, the board isn’t overly complex. To the naked eye, this is a relatively simple game. Why 10/10? Because the beauty of this game is the players playing it. There’s no luck, no dice rolls, no cards, just you and the other players negotiating, promising, betraying, and fighting for European supremacy. You need to form alliances and know when the time is right to break those alliances. The best way I can describe this game is it’s all about the human experience. Any real strategy board gamer needs to play this game at some point in their life. There are 2 downsides to the game: if you can’t find 7 players to play a full game the experience is diminished. There are ways to still play the game with less than 7, but the more players involved the better the game. Diplomacy tends to take a large amount of time, so finding 7 players that are committed to spending a day playing this game can be challenging. That being said, you will not beat the experienced of a 7 player game of diplomacy.

This is the most intense and immersive game I've ever played, period. FTF, this occupies six-plus hours of time fully and completely, with no time or or even inclination to do anything else. Even a called bathroom break is a time for intense negotiation. As PBEM, you can spend as much time crafting the exact right language to your neighbor in the game as you spend drafting the exact right language to send to your client...and it's debatable which one you subjectively feel is more important! Simply a brilliantly crafted game. It isn't for everyone, but for those who can laugh at the end and recognize that it really was just a game, it may well be the best gaming experience ever.

The best game of negotiation.

No random and simultaneous choice is the key of its success.

A good mix of strategy, bluff, seduction and psychology makes it one of the richest games.

Can be played only with 7 players for a balanced game.
Fantastic game that will permanently break the trust your friends have placed in you, if you can get 7 interested friends together to play it.
Literally my favorite game. Always trying to get people to play, but you have to be bold to tackle this gem!

This is one of my favorite games of all time. It's not for everybody, but it pulls out aspects of human nature that other games ignore completely. It is a long, interactive game with very simple choices in a simultaneous action resolution system. What makes the game is talking to other people. I've had games that I won where I felt terrible for backstabbing my closest friends, and games where my friends stuck by me when the whole table was against me. I've had games where I wasn't certain whether I was helping somebody or manipulating them. This is a game that is always intense and interesting, and I love it.

I haven't played this often, but every time I play it is a genuine event and never fails to be interesting.
Love this game! Want to play more!
Génial !
You will lose all your friends but it will be worth it.

A fine, all skill game requiring a cool, strategic mind, a command of the art of diplomacy, and a ruthless streak a mile long.

A genuinely fantastic game, but it must be played by the right group of people. I've seen friendships come to bitter ends because of this game, and indeed I would never again play this with any of my pals.

BUT... if you can find the right people, and if they know how to play, the game can be nothing short of a work of art.

Hell of a game. Hard work. Its nature is quite incomparable. A genre of its own.

Probably never going to play it again.

One of the best experiences I have had board gaming. So much so, that I wrote and showcased a whole presentation about my experience with the game for a college class. Not many games could be showcased in such a way and draw admiring "Oooh"s and "ahhh!"s from students as I recount the many bloody betrayals and highstakes interaction between players. If there is one complaint I have, it would be the sticky situation of hurt feelings after an especially cruel backstab between close friends. For that, I highly recommend anonymous online services.
This is how games should be
Intense game where the outcome are driven by players dealing with each other.

Easily one of my favorite games. The cliche, "diplomacy can ruin friendships" can be true. To avoid this pitfall it is best that players set table rules for conduct, language, etc. When playing in person it is also best to plan on fun activities for eliminated players.
A brilliantly simple game that focuses purely on negotiation; the barebones war mechanics serve only as a vehicle to drive player negotiation, alliances and backstabs.

I've only played one game of Diplomacy, but it was one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've had. I love the epic feel and treachery. One of the best games I've played. It's great fun to learn how to be a master manipulator and to know how to get people to trust you and when to betray them. Diplomacy is a great way to learn about the prisoners' dilemma. I can't wait to play again.
An all-time classic!
